questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with severe pain in his bilateral hips, arms and diffuse body aches. He had similar episodes in the past but was never hospitalised. Laboratory investigations are normal except for a total bilirubin of 1.5 mg/dL and suggestive of microcytic anemia. His peripheral smear is shown. What is the most likely pathogenesis of the given condition?

options.label: A
options.text: A somatic mutation that causes deranged messenger RNA splicing of the globin gene.

options.label: C
options.text: Mutation in the β-globin gene that changes the sixth amino acid from glutamic acid to valine.

options.label: D
options.text: One of the four α-globin loci is deleted.

questions.correct_answer: C. Mutation in the β-globin gene that changes the sixth amino acid from glutamic acid to valine.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mutation in the β-globin gene that changes the sixth amino acid from glutamic acid to valine. The peripheral smear shows elongated and crescent-shaped red blood cells, target cells and a nucleated red blood cell. James B Herrick was the first person who describes sickle cell anemia in 1910. He told them as peculiar elongated, sickle-shaped red blood cells in a case of severe anemia. It is produced due to single point mutation from the substitution of valine for glutamic acid at the 6th position of the β chain. Sickle cell anemia is when HbS is the only Hb present, such as in Homozygous HbS(HbSS). Sickle cell trait is defined as the inheritance of the HbS from one Parent but a normal HbA gene from the other. Erythrocyte deformation, or sickling, is initially reversible, but after an undetermined number of cell sickling events, the cell becomes irreversibly deformed. These are known as irreversibly sickled cells (ISCs). Sickle erythrocytes lead to the clinical and laboratory phenotypes of disease. Sickle cells interact with endothelial cells and other blood cells, occluding flow in small and sometimes large vessels and causing the many complications thought to be a result of vaso occlusion.

The normal Hemoglobin(Hb A) in adults contains 2 α and 2β chains. A mutation in the globin gene causes sickle cell anemia(HbS). HbS -β Valine replaces 6 Position Glutamic acid HbC -β Lysine replaces 6 Position Glutamic acid HbE -β Lysine replaces 26 Position Glutamic Acid

questions.text: All of the following are provocative factors for the painful crisis in Sickle cell syndrome EXCEPT?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bed rest Acute painful episodes are the most common critical events in sickle cell disease. It is characterised by unprovoked severe pain in the extremities or torso that is often symmetrical and stereotypical and usually requires treatment with potent opioids. Provocative factors include infection, fever, excessive exercise, anxiety, abrupt changes in temperature, hypoxia, or hypertonic dyes. All patients will experience it at some point. It is the most common reason for hospitalization. Vaso-occlusive episode -defined as new onset pain lasting for> 4 hours with no alternative explanation, requiring analgesics. Sudden deaths-due from Arrhythmias or pulmonary embolism Predictors of severe crisis or multi-organ failure- drastic drop in hemoglobin, a drastic drop in platelet counts, and extreme leukocytosis. Pathophysiology- In SCA, the intracellular concentration of HbS is almost 100% . The fundamental event in pathophysiology is the polymerisation of HbS. The damaged RBCs are less flexible and highly adhesive. Repeated cycles of sickling and unsickling- SHORTEN the RBCs lifespan—>Occlusion of blood vessels in every body organ—--> trigger inflammatory cascade—- ->vascular endothelial dysfunction and chronic organ damage. The diagrammatic representation is as follows. HbS is physiologically similar to HbA in most aspects in the Oxygenated form. Once deoxygenated, it polymerises. Post-capillary venules are small and deoxygenated areas with maximum damage. Hence if we prevent the deoxygenation of HbS, we can avoid the pathological manifestations of the disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about stroke in Sickle cell syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: More common in children, and a small subset tends to suffer repeated episodes.

options.label: B
options.text: More common in adults and is often ischemic.

options.label: D
options.text: More common in adults but non-recurrent

questions.correct_answer: A. More common in children, and a small subset tends to suffer repeated episodes.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

More common in children, and a small subset tends to suffer repeated episodes. The risk of stroke in untreated sickle cell disease patients is around 10-15%. The risk factors for stroke in these patients-Anemia, are leukocytosis and hypertension. In a patient with newly diagnosed sickle cell anemia risk of stroke is decreased by annual screening with TCD(trans cranial doppler) from 2 years of age to 16 years annually and giving them chronic transfusion therapy indefinitely based on the results. Hydroxyurea(inducing high levels of HbF) effectively prevents stroke in patients with abnormal transcranial Doppler. Chronic transfusion therapy is helpful in primary and secondary stroke prevention.

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B & D. Stroke is less common in adults and is often hemorrhagic. Option: C. Repeated episodes may be seen. The risk of recurrence is around 60%.

questions.text: What is the most common site of the Sequestration crisis in children with Sickle cell syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Spleen Acute splenic sequestration is seen in 1-4 years of age. Thrombosis of the venous outﬂow from an organ causes loss of function and acute painful enlargement. In children, the spleen is the most common site. Diagnosed by sudden enlarged and tender spleen, drop in hemoglobin by 2gm%, increased Reticulocyte count, Thrombocytopenia, and Hypovolemia. In younger patients, we can diagnose it by acute anemia and hypovolemic shock. In older patients, there is insidiously progressing splenomegaly with anemia. After an episode of sequestration, s plenic size should be monitored. Treatment is iv hydration and transfusion to maintain Hb around 8gm%.splenectomy is considered if symptoms are progressive despite conservative management.

questions.text: What is the cause of the Aplastic crisis in Sickle cell syndrome?
questions.correct_answer: D. Infection with human parvovirus B19
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Infection with human parvovirus B19 Anemia in a patient of sickle cell disease can be due to aplastic crisis, hemolysis, sequestration, or Epo deficiency(CKD -renal complication) Aplastic crisis: Typically seen in infections with human parvovirus B19, pneumococcus, EBV. The reticulocyte count is low. In hemolytic crisis-Rbc life span can be as low as 17 days(usually 120 days). Here Reticulocyte count is high.
